titleInfo.title: Louisiana Cooperative Extension Oral History Project
titleInfo.subTitle: Dr. Paul Coreil oral history interview, 2014

name.description: Paul Dean Coreil was born on September 9, 1955, in Ville Platte, Louisiana. He is the son of Armand Bertrand Coreil and Juanita Smith. He grew up in Ville Platte, where he attended high school at Sacred Heart Catholic School. In 1976 he graduated with a B.S. in zoology from the University of Southwestern Louisiana. He later attended Louisiana State University where he received a master's degree in wildlife management in 1984 and a Ph.D. in vocational education in 1995. Coreil was involved in the Louisiana Cooperative Extension Service for most of his career. In 1978 he was hired as an assistant area agent for wildlife and fisheries. He also served as Parish Chairman of Cameron Parish LCES, associate specialist of wetland and coastal resources in the state LCES office, and as assistant director of the Louisiana Cooperative Extension Service. In 2001 he was appointed Vice Chancellor and Director of Louisiana Cooperative Extension Service. He retired from LCES in September 2013 and served for a short time as the interim chancellor of LSU-Alexandria.

subject.topic: Ville Platte (La.)--Social life and customs--20th century.

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: Coreil begins the interview by discussing his parents, his early farm life, and working on a farm as a teenager. He details his job as a student worker studying nutria and how that led him to a job with extension services. He describes moving to Cameron Parish, establishing a sea-grant extension program, and the challenges he faced while on the job. These include the Endangered Species Act of the 1970s, a time when shrimpers blockaded a federal ship channel, installing new phone lines in the parish extension office, and how the first computers impacted extension. He also details how farmers now utilize information on the Internet vs. getting it from county agents, the devastation of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, and how Louisiana Cooperative Extension played a vital role in helping to recover from the storms. He describes what it takes to be successful in extension services and discusses the future of the extension model.
